item.title: Your Options For Business Internet Broadband
item.description: By: John Shepler Businesses now have more choices than ever when it comes to broadband internet. Let’s examine the available solutions suitable for companies of all sizes. Starting Big Gigabit internet is the ideal scenario for most, but affordability can be a concern. Medium to large companies in most areas, and even smaller businesses in specific locations, might find it within reach. Location, Location, Location Your business address significantly impacts both the available services and their costs.

item.title: Business DSL Alternatives
What To Do If You Hate Your Internet Service
item.description: Many people express frustration about their internet speed or lack of broadband access. While high-bandwidth options might not always be suitable, there are solutions for individuals and small businesses. Broadband access is a pressing issue, so much so that the government is investing significantly to expand coverage in underserved areas. While this will eventually improve access, universal coverage like electricity or telephone service is not yet feasible. In remote areas, wireless internet is often the best option.

item.title: When Asymmetrical Bandwidth Works Just Fine
item.description: Businesses have often dismissed asymmetrical bandwidth in favor of symmetrical options, sometimes leading to unnecessary expenses or frustratingly slow speeds. How do these symmetries work? Symmetrical bandwidth offers identical upload and download speeds, often labeled as 3 x 3 Mbps Ethernet or 100 x 100 Mbps Fast Ethernet. A classic example is the T1 line, with a fixed 1.5 Mbps for both uploading and downloading. T1, DS3, and SONET exemplify symmetrical bandwidth services, a legacy of their development by telephone companies for bulk voice calls, requiring equal bandwidth in both directions.

item.title: High Speed Internet For Business
item.description: In recent years, high-speed internet access has become widely available and affordable for businesses. Numerous broadband options exist, even in remote areas. Let’s explore a variety of high-speed internet connections, categorized by low, medium, and high bandwidth. While businesses might desire high bandwidth, most don’t require extremely high speeds. Generally, higher bandwidth means higher cost. However, prices within bandwidth categories can vary. Shared service options are less expensive than dedicated services but offer less stable bandwidth.
